title: Beaver Creek Hydrology [DRAFT]
text:
Preface
In Spring 2022, the United States Geological Survey (USGS) initiated a partnership with Kenai Watershed Forum (KWF) with support from the Alaska Climate Action Science Center (AK CASC). The project will investigate hydrological conditions in the Beaver Creek watershed, a lowland tributary of the Kenai River. The project will use present-day data on water temperature, discharge, and landscape characteristics to model future conditions under future scenarios of climate conditions and groundwater usage.
This document is a draft in progress and is for use only in disseminating information among the research team. All data is preliminary and has not been approved for use in publications by USGS or any other entity, as of 2023-04-12

title: 1  Methods
text:
1.1 Water Temperature Loggers

1.1.1 Locations
Our project includes water temperature data from a total of fifteen locations throughout the Beaver Creek watershed. In summer 2022 we established thirteen sites to monitor water temperature with HOBO TempPro v2 loggers, in addition to the one site previously established by Kenai Watershed Forum. The USGS Alaska Science Center also established a real-time discharge monitoring station, which records water temperature in addition to discharge.
Site location and other metadata are available for download in the link below.





Download Temperature Logger Site Metadata for USGS / KWF Beaver Creek Hydrology Project



An ArcGIS Online map of site locations is displayed below. The map may also be accessed at https://arcg.is/0ySarv1.



View larger map




1.1.2 QA/QC Checks

1.1.2.1 Pre-deployment
Prior to deployment, all water temperature loggers undergo a QA/QC check as described in (Mauger et al. 2015).


1.1.2.2 Post-deployment
Data was downloaded from all loggers in September/October 2022, and reviewed in Spring 2023. Each time series was visually inspected in an R Shiny plot for data that is non-representative of stream channel conditions, such as exposure to air or burial in sand.
Segments of each time series identified as non-representative of stream channel conditions were flagged in a seperate csv file, then applied to flag and remove these









Visually designate flagged data



Plot time series again with flagged data in red






Records for time periods flagged for individual loggers are recorded and available to view at the download below.


Download Temperature Logger Flagged Data Records





This script was developed with assistance from Dr. Jose Bentancourt in April 2023: https://www.linkedin.com/in/djbetancourt/
Test




Mauger, Sue, Rebecca Shaftel, E Jamie Trammell, Marcus Geist, and Dan Bogan. 2015. “Stream Temperature Data Collection Standards for Alaska: Minimum Standards to Generate Data Useful for Regional-Scale Analyses.” Journal of Hydrology: Regional Studies 4, Part B (September): 431–38. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.ejrh.2015.07.008.
